Workplace trends

Flexibility

Luxury rental buildings are elevating work from home

While a growing number of employees have come to see remote work as a must, many do not want to be clocking in from their kitchen tables or living room couches anymore. That's why more and more new luxury apartment buildings around the country are flaunting beautiful office spaces and conference rooms as the latest additions to their lists of desirable amenities. In most of these buildings, the workspaces are included in the rent price, but some landlords have begun to charge a fee to reserve rooms for larger groups or for extended periods of time. And co-working companies like Industrious and WeWork are starting to take notice, hoping not to get edged out of the market.

Legal

Glassdoor reviews might not stay so anonymous

Last week, a U.S. judge ruled that Glassdoor, the anonymous workplace review site, would need to reveal the identities behind six harsh reviews of Zuru - a New Zealand toy company. The logic? Given that the identities of the employees are most likely not U.S. citizens, they are probably not protected by U.S. free speech laws. This decision not only threatens Glassdoor's privacy policy, but potentially its entire business model given that the company's $1.2 billion business hinges on users from around the world using the platform to honestly and transparently review nearly 2.2 million companies - and those users do so under the assumption that their reviews will stay completely anonymous.

Economy

Truckers are demanding continued independence

Hundreds of truckers are protesting a controversial worker classification bill by cutting off access to California's Port of Oakland - the third-busiest port on the West Coast. The bill, known as AB5, is meant to give workers greater access to benefits like health insurance by forcing large companies to classify more workers as employees, rather than independent contractors. So, what's the problem for California truckers? The drivers who work as independent owners and operators claim that AB5 would mean less flexibility and higher costs to remain independent. Meanwhile, though neither the governor nor the drivers seem to be budging, the protest is exacerbating supply-chain issues with cargo ship traffic jams and stockpiled goods languishing on the dock.

Increasing a sense of connectedness on your team

by monday.com

Everyone seems to be blaming remote work for the lack of real human connection in the office. And while it certainly plays a role, new research reveals that in fact, the most common culprit is actually company culture.

Many organizations claim that their people are their greatest assets, yet not everyone knows how to really utilize them. According to a new study by BetterUp Labs, 43% of workers think their company should be doing more to promote workplace connections and 53% would actually trade some compensation for more meaningful relationships with colleagues. Why does this matter? Well, this same research revealed that individuals with few connections in the workplace are 73% less engaged than their highly-connected peers, and those experiencing lower levels of belonging reported 109% more burnout and have a 313% stronger intention to quit than their more connected counterparts. So, while so many people seem to value human connection at work, not enough is being done by employers to support that sense of belonging that many employees are seeking.

How can managers support employee connectedness?

Though ultimately it's up to each individual to invest in their workplace friendships, managers are responsible for creating a culture in which employees can connect and feel they belong.

Employees who feel a strong sense of belonging said they had 24% greater resilience, 36% healthier wellbeing, and 92% more professional growth. That's why, it's important for managers to:

Prioritize cultural fit in the hiring process

When hiring new candidates to join your team, be sure to take their people skills into account and consider how they would fit your team dynamics. Hard skills are important, but in many cases these can be taught. In contrast, innate social skills are much harder to impart on employees. So, during the hiring interview, try to gauge the candidate's energy and enthusiasm about collaborating with others. Also, rather than just focusing on whether their skills are what you're looking for, really think to yourself, "could I picture this person on my team?"

Loop other team members into onboarding

Set your new hires up for success by helping them build connections from the get-go. Designate a relevant team member to be your new hire's peer mentor or buddy to make the transition smoother and ensure they have a contact they can go to for guidance.

Additionally, before a new hire's first day, send an announcement to the whole team to let them know about the upcoming addition to the group, and encourage them to set up time during the new hire's first few weeks for brief, non-work related intros. In those announcements, it can be helpful to include a few personal details about the new joiner coming on board. Additionally, a welcome lunch or coffee with the team on the new employee's first day is always a great way to start making them feel comfortable and help them build familiarity with their colleagues.

Encourage collaboration and team feedback

It's important to build a culture in which team members feel safe acknowledging that they don't know everything. This means, encouraging individuals to ask questions in meetings, share feedback, and make suggestions, without feeling like they're being judged or tested. As a manager, you can set the tone for this by designating time during your weekly meetings for team members to present what they are working on and get feedback from others.

Organize non-work related time together

Create opportunities for smaller, less formal time for your team members to get to know each other in a non-work setting. Social activities like happy hours, team-building exercises, and shared meals outside the workplace are a great way to promote a healthy corporate culture and give your team members the opportunity to have organic and open conversations with others in their organization.

Even in remote work settings, it's still possible and beneficial to schedule non-work-related meetings with the team to create space for more casual and light-hearted exchanges.

Water cooler chatter

The oldest galaxy in the known universe was just discovered by the James Webb Space Telescope. The blurry red dot in the image is actually showing a galaxy that formed just 300 million years after the big bang, which happened 13.7 billion years ago. That's 100 million years older than the previous oldest pictured galaxy.

"If these candidates are confirmed spectroscopically, it is clear that JWST will prove highly successful in pushing the cosmic frontier all the way to the brink of the Big Bang."

- Study led by Rohan Naidu, Harvard University graduate student in astronomy

Quidditch has rebranded itself to "quadball" in an effort to distance the sport from Harry Potter author JK Rowling, who they say has anti-transgender views. While it originated in the popular children's book, Quadball now has nearly 600 teams spread across 40+ countries.

"The name change indicates a firm stance with our trans players and members, as well as giving us more firm legal footing and opening up greater opportunities for funding and external partners."

- QuidditchUK
